items.title: Allow custom scoring function for ARIMA() and AutoARIMA()
items.body: Currently, AutoARIMA optimizes ARIMA to achieve the lowest score according to its "scoring" parameter. This parameter can specify either mean-squared error or mean-absolute error. It would be extremely helpful to specify other error metrics from `sklearn.metrics`, or pass to arbitrary callables that take similar kwargs. This could allow greater flexibility for customizing the optimization than specifying sample weights in `scoring_args`.

items.title: How can I specify different trends?
items.body:
Hello,
I have a short Question concerning Trends in the "auto_arima" command.
Suprisingly I couldn't find anything in other issues, the documentation or blog Posts, so ist probably obvious but I'm not getting it :)

In the statmodels documentation I read that in their ARIMA the trend is either equal "c" which is a constant or "nc" which is no constant. In "auto_arima" the constant is however handled by "with_intercept" which if "True" includes a constant.

Thus my Question is, how can a trend be included into the model? And if the trend component should be used, as is suggested in the exogenous part of the documentation "This should not include a constant or trend", what kinds of strings can be used to apply different trend methods.
Further, can the trend be modelled customly, as i would like to include a linear trend , with trend shifts (slope changes)?

Thank a lot for your help and time.

items.title: Checking for near non-invertible roots in auto_arima is subsequently ignored
items.body:
**Describe the bug**
Checking for near non-invertible roots occurs in `_auto_solvers._root_test(model, ic, trace)` - this returns `np.inf` if the roots are near non-invertible. 

However, the return value from `_root_test` is only used to determine which model should be saved as `.bestfit` during a stepwise parameter search. The actual model IC remains unmodified and the model itself is stored in `.results_dict` for onward calculation. In the non-stepwise approach, this test is not performed at all.

Once the parameter search has finished, all the results are fitltered for None in `auto._post_ppc_arima` and then sorted according to the IC. Assuming only one model is required, `auto._return_wrapper` returns the value at the top of the list. The root testing is therefore ignored as the only possible effect it can have is on the model stored in `.bestfit`, which is not used outside the stepwise calculation.

In the R version of the code, it appears that the root testing modifies the IC of the actual model (setting it to Inf) and therefore the model will be ignored in subsequent calculations.


**To Reproduce**  
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
Run a stepwise parameter search, where the model with the lowest AIC has near non-invertible roots


**Versions**
Darwin-18.7.0-x86_64-i386-64bit
Python 3.7.4 (default, Oct 12 2019, 18:55:28) 
[Clang 11.0.0 (clang-1100.0.33.8)]
pmdarima 1.5.3
NumPy 1.18.2
SciPy 1.4.1
Scikit-Learn 0.22.2.post1
Statsmodels 0.11.1

**Expected behavior**
All models with near non-invertible roots should be discarded. Of the remaining models, the model with the lowest AIC should be selected

**Actual behavior**
The model with the lowest AIC is selected, regardless of whether the roots are near non-invertible

**Additional context**
Having a quick look at the R code, it seems that the root testing modifies the IC of the model itself, which would avoid this issue occurring ( https://github.com/robjhyndman/forecast/blob/master/R/newarima2.R#L780 )

Incidentally, the final model order on the stepwise search is reported from the `.bestfit` paramater of the model ( https://github.com/alkaline-ml/pmdarima/blob/master/pmdarima/arima/_auto_solvers.py#L342 ) but this may not reflect the final values selected.

items.title: How does auto_arima handle transformations of exogenous variables?
items.body:
Hi,

I've looked through past issues and the source code for auto_arima and couldn't find a clear answer to this.  Will auto_arima explore any transformations of exogenous variables that are passed in to the function?  For example, if the best-fit model lands on ARIMA(1,1,1), can I expect that a first-order differencing was also applied to the X variable(s) as well?  Or would I need to manually difference my X variable(s) before passing them into auto_arima?  Aside from differencing, what about lags or other possible transformations?  Thank you!

items.title: Update endogenous variables without re-fitting model
items.body:
**Question**
I have split a time series into a training set and a test set. I fit my model on my training set. 

I am looking for a way to test my data one point at a time, using every previous point in the model (essentially, I want to do cross validation on my test data). However, I _do not_ want to refit my model for every test point. I simply want to fit my model once, but be able to add endogenous data later (my motivation is that fitting many times is prohibitively slow since my m is relatively high). 

So far, I have tried using the CV module and the update method for the ARIMA model. Even with maxiter = 0, however, the update method still refits the data. The CV module also refits the data at every point. I also tried using the out_of_sample_size parameter, but that did not seem to be what I was looking for either.

The documentation around the update method hints that this is possible. I was wondering if I missed something, or if this is just not supported?

I'm a newbie, trying to use auto-arima for a basic implementation and run into some issues, I'm not sure if it's a malfunction of the API or my lack of understanding and hope you could help me:

items.title: "ValueError: operands could not be broadcast together" raised when decomposing with odd frequencies
items.body:
**Describe the bug**

Executing `arima.decompose` with `m` equal to an odd number (for example, `m=3`) throws an error `ValueError: operands could not be broadcast together with shapes (<N>,) (<N-1>,)` (Where `N` is the length of the data being decomposed).



**To Reproduce**  
Steps to reproduce the behavior:

```python
tarray =np.array([1.,2.,3.,4.,5.,6.,])
arima.decompose(tarray, 'additive', m=3)
```
**Versions**
```
System:
    python: 3.7.3 (v3.7.3:ef4ec6ed12, Mar 25 2019, 22:22:05) [MSC v.1916 64 bit (AMD64)]
executable: C:\REDACTED_PATH_TO_A_VENV\python.exe
   machine: Windows-10-10.0.15063-SP0

Python dependencies:
        pip: 20.0.2
 setuptools: 46.1.3
    sklearn: 0.22.2.post1
statsmodels: 0.11.1
      numpy: 1.18.2
      scipy: 1.4.1
     Cython: 0.29.16
     pandas: 1.0.3
     joblib: 0.14.1
   pmdarima: 1.5.3
```

**Expected behavior**

Expected a decomposition of a trend with a seasonal period ("frequency") of some odd number of intervals.  Or at least a clearer explanation that `m` can only take even values.

**Actual behavior**
Function throws exception:
`ValueError: operands could not be broadcast together with shapes`

**Additional context**

I believe the issue comes from these parts of seasonality.py:

``` python
    # Take half of m for the convolution / sma process.
    half_m = m // 2
```
and 
``` python
    # We buffer the trend and seasonal components so that they are the same
    # length as the other outputs. This counters the effects of losing data
    # by the convolution/sma
    buffer = [np.nan] * half_m
    trend = list(buffer + trend.tolist() + buffer)
```

When `m` is odd, the length of `trend` is one shorter than `x` and therefore `m - trend` cannot be calculated.

I would guess that, for `m` odd, adding an extra `[np.nan]` to either the right hand buffer or the left hand buffer would fix the exception, but I don't follow the maths well enough to know if that would cause problems with the actual decomposition and/or whether this issue should be chased through to other sections of the code.

Exception thrown is very similar to that in #30 .

items.title: Differencing as subtracting the previous observation from the current observation or vice versa?
items.body:
**Question**
Can you please explain whether differencing should be done as X(t-1) - X(t) [as pmdarima is doing] instead of X(t) - X(t-1). For example, on page: http://alkaline-ml.com/pmdarima/tips_and_tricks.html#understanding-differencing-d
there is a code:

```
x = c(10, 4, 2, 9, 34)

# 1
x_lag = x[1:]  # first lag
x = x_lag - x[:-1]  # first difference
# x = [ -6.,  -2.,   7.,  25.]

# 2
x_lag = x[1:]  # second lag
x = x_lag - x[:-1]
# x = [ 4.,  9., 18.]
```
in which you do `x = x_lag - x[:-1]` instead of `x = x[:-1] - x_lag`.
I don't say it is wrong, I am just asking for double check, because on many sites I have found the second approach:
1. https://machinelearningmastery.com/difference-time-series-dataset-python/  (difference(t) = observation(t) - observation(t-1))
2. https://otexts.com/fpp2/stationarity.html (chapter Second-order differencing)
3. https://nwfsc-timeseries.github.io/atsa-labs/sec-tslab-differencing-to-remove-a-trend-or-seasonal-effects.html
...

Can you please check?

items.title: 'Aicc' in case of out_of_sample_size wrong?
items.body:
```
def _aicc(model_results, nobs, add_constant):
    """Compute the corrected Akaike Information Criterion"""
    aic = model_results.aic

    # SARIMAX counts the constant in df_model if there was an intercept, so
    # only add one if no constant was included in the model
    df_model = model_results.df_model
    if add_constant:
        add_constant += 1  # add one for constant term
    return aic + 2. * df_model * (nobs / (nobs - df_model - 1.) - 1.)
```

```
 def update(self, y, exogenous=None, maxiter=None, **kwargs):
   .
   .
   . 
  # Get the model parameters, then we have to "fit" a new one. If you're
        # reading this source code, don't panic! We're not just fitting a new
        # arbitrary model. Statsmodels does not handle patching new samples in
        # very well, so we seed the new model with the existing parameters.
        params = model_res.params
        self._fit(y, exog, start_params=params, maxiter=maxiter, **kwargs)
```


When we use out_of_sample_size parameter in auto_arima, we fit the model using existing parameters as seed parameters and data as insample and outsample combined. I am guessing, retraining it will change the aic value too of the trained model( it should)

However, while calculating aicc, nobs is the number of observations in insample data. While the update routine was run on (insample + outsample) data. Shouldn't nobs be updated to account for that?

items.title: How does auto_arima with out_of_sample_size specified select a model?
items.body:
Hello,
I had a question on how pmdarima treats out_of_sample_size parameter. 

**Objective**
To select the best model paramaters on the basis of out_of_sample scoring instead of insample scoring using **auto_arima**. 

**My Readings**
I had gone through some documentation on how to cross-validate time series model using pmdarima( https://alkaline-ml.com/pmdarima/auto_examples/model_selection/example_cross_validation.html#sphx-glr-auto-examples-model-selection-example-cross-validation-py ). However in this example, we are explicitly specifying the model parameters for 2 different models and then checking cross_val_score.

**Question**
On specifying out_of_sample_size in auto_arima, does it automatically select best model parameters on the basis of out_of_sample cross_validation scores? If no, then on what basis is the best model parameters chosen? 

I read the arima.py file and found these:
```
if cv:
            cv_samples = y[-cv:]
            y = y[:-cv]

            # This also means we have to address the exogenous matrix
            if exogenous is not None:
                cv_exog = exogenous[-cv:, :]
                exogenous = exogenous[:-cv, :]
```

```
# now make a forecast if we're validating to compute the
        # out-of-sample score
        if cv_samples is not None:
            # get the predictions (use self.predict, which calls forecast
            # from statsmodels internally)
            pred = self.predict(n_periods=cv, exogenous=cv_exog)
            self.oob_ = scoring(cv_samples, pred, **self.scoring_args)

            # If we compute out of sample scores, we have to now update the
            # observed time points so future forecasts originate from the end
            # of our y vec
            self.add_new_observations(cv_samples, cv_exog)
```

While I can see that the out of sample score(self,oob_) is produced, where is it consumed(if it is)/is it used to find the bestfit?

Please let me know if something is not clear.

I have a list of 5000 clients and I have to run auto_arima for all of them. The model is to be eventually trained on client level i.e. my code will train a different model for the 5000 clients I have. I will be using multiprocessing to divide these clients among different cores. Eg. Process 1 does the computation for first 1000 clients, Process 2 does for next 1000 and so on parallely.

Since auto_arima is automatically using the resources of all cores(should not be the case), my client level multiprocessing approach is actually performing worse since the client level processes have to wait for the resources to get free.

Also, If you have any suggestion how this could be leveraged, I would be thankful.
 
I posted a question on stackoverflow as well and the discussion can be accessed here: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/60294725/python-sarima-model-is-automatically-using-all-cores-of-cpu-how

This is my first time posting a question on github. Please let me know if I can supply any other info.

items.title: auto_arima often fails to find a model with statsmodel 0.11.0
items.body:
**Describe the bug**
auto_arima often fails to find a model with statsmodel 0.11 and throws the ValueError: "Could not successfully fit ARIMA to input data. It is likely your data is non-stationary. Please induce stationarity or try a different range of model order params. If your data is seasonal, check the period (m) of the data."
This is very undesirable for a general forecasting solution - in our case, we'd always prefer to fit a model, even if it's not a great one. I understand this is likely more of a statsmodels issue, but maybe you all can shed some light on the differences in the latest stable statsmodels version and if you have plans to work around this.
As an example, I have a unit test using some synthetic data that passed with older versions of statsmodels (i.e. <=0.10.2) but now always fails with 0.11.0. Main code from the test is below.  

**To Reproduce**  
Steps to reproduce the behavior:

```python
import numpy as np
import pmdarima

time_index = np.arange(20)
amplitude = 15.0
offset = 85.0
period = 5
signal_vals = np.sin(time_index / period * 2 * np.pi) * amplitude + offset

# Compute noise values
noise_amplitude = 3.0
noise_vals = np.random.uniform(low=-noise_amplitude, high=noise_amplitude, size=(time_index.size,))

# Combine and model
vals = signal_vals + noise_vals
pmdarima.arima.auto_arima(vals)
```

**Versions**
1.5.2

items.title: Should error in predict_in_sample when start < d
items.body:
When creating an ARIMA model with a differencing of more than 0 it should be impossible to get the prediction of the model for the index 0.

However, when calling predict_in_sample with start=0 on an ARIMA model with a differencing of 1 or more it will return a value for the index 0. And when calling this function with return_conf_int=True the confidences intervals for this specific first value are not coherent (extremely big values).

As explained at the end of this page: https://www.statsmodels.org/dev/generated/statsmodels.tsa.arima_model.ARIMAResults.predict.html#statsmodels.tsa.arima_model.ARIMAResults.predict
It might be a good idea to throw an error when trying to call the function with a start "out of range".

items.title: failure when fitting arima model with out_of_sample_size and a pandas dataframe exogenous
items.body:
to reproduce:
```
arima_model = arima.ARIMA(order=(0, 1, 0), out_of_sample_size=int(len(y)*0.2))
model.fit(y, exogenous)
```

in `arima.py`, line 463 is currently:
```
                cv_exog = exogenous[-cv:, :]
                exogenous = exogenous[:-cv, :]
``` 

when exogenous is a pandas dataframe with non-integer (date) index, it fails with `'(slice(-115, None, None), slice(None, None, None))' is an invalid key` 

should be:

```
                cv_exog = exogenous.iloc[-cv:, :]
                exogenous = exogenous.iloc[:-cv, :]
```

items.title: auto_arima IC values different after fitting with same orders
items.body:
I applied the auto_arima method onto a [dataset](https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/INVCMRMT) and received the following trace output:

```
Fit ARIMA: order=(0, 1, 0) seasonal_order=(0, 0, 0, 0); AIC=5348.037, BIC=5355.181, Fit time=0.019 seconds
Fit ARIMA: order=(1, 1, 0) seasonal_order=(0, 0, 0, 0); AIC=5399.843, BIC=5410.560, Fit time=0.079 seconds
Fit ARIMA: order=(0, 1, 1) seasonal_order=(0, 0, 0, 0); AIC=5350.241, BIC=5360.957, Fit time=0.054 seconds
Fit ARIMA: order=(0, 1, 0) seasonal_order=(0, 0, 0, 0); AIC=5409.217, BIC=5412.789, Fit time=0.011 seconds
Fit ARIMA: order=(1, 1, 1) seasonal_order=(0, 0, 0, 0); AIC=5378.835, BIC=5393.124, Fit time=0.256 seconds
Total fit time: 0.424 seconds
```
Parameters used:
- information_criterion: aic
- start_p/q = 0
- max_p/q = 2
- seasonal = False
- stationary = False

The first fitting seems to correspond to fitting using the statsmodels ARIMA method, but the second fitting is using the statsmodels SARIMAX method. The 'Fit ARIMA' print-out was misleading, but more importantly, even with the information_criterion parameter set to use AIC the method chose SARIMAX over ARIMA. Is there a reason why this might be the case?

items.title: Update requirements
items.body:
Hi, first of all thanks for working to make this package happen!

The package [requires](https://github.com/alkaline-ml/pmdarima/blob/master/setup.py#L243) a Python version of `3.5` or above. It also requires the discontinued `pathlib` package on PyPI. [Pathlib](https://docs.python.org/3/library/pathlib.html) has been a part of the standard library since `3.4`. And `six` is a package for Python 2-3 compatibility, but it uses `string_types` and `with_metaclass`, both of which have Python 3 only variants [[1](https://six.readthedocs.io/#six.string_types)] [[2](https://six.readthedocs.io/#six.add_metaclass)].

Is there something I've not quite understood? If not, should the requirements and code be updated? At the very least one could use [`pathlib2`](https://pypi.org/project/pathlib2/), which is the successor of `pathlib` on PyPI.

items.title: tsdisplay equivalent
items.body: Whenever I see a cool feature in R that I want, my first stop is to check whether statsmodels supports it natively. If so, we should use their implementation. If not, we should add it. This is one of the cases where R's [`tsplot`](https://www.rdocumentation.org/packages/astsa/versions/1.9/topics/tsplot) is not implemented in statsmodels and it would be nice if we had an equivalent.

items.title: arima.update without refitting?
items.body:
the `arima.update` code specifically says:

```
        # Get the model parameters, then we have to "fit" a new one. If you're
        # reading this source code, don't panic! We're not just fitting a new
        # arbitrary model. Statsmodels does not handle patching new samples in
        # very well, so we seed the new model with the existing parameters.
```

can you please explain the `Statsmodels does not handle patching new samples in very well`? if you can share the experience you had and what APIs did you try... It just doesn't make sense to me to waste even one MLE iteration on this, since I want the fitted model without any change - I just want to update the underlying `endog` and `exog`.

     ```

N/A

items.title: How to wrap VarianceThreshold into a pipeline?
Is there any way to get model parameters
items.body:
<!-- Before asking a question, please consult our closed issues and docs to see
if we have already addressed it:

https://github.com/alkaline-ml/pmdarima/issues?q=is%3Aissue+is%3Aclosed
https://www.alkaline-ml.com/pmdarima/
-->

**Question**
<!-- A clear and concise description of the issue you're experiencing, and under what conditions -->

**Versions (if necessary)**
<!--
Please run the following snippet and paste the output below.
import platform; print(platform.platform())
import sys; print("Python", sys.version)
import pmdarima; print("pmdarima", pmdarima.__version__)
import numpy; print("NumPy", numpy.__version__)
import scipy; print("SciPy", scipy.__version__)
import sklearn; print("Scikit-Learn", sklearn.__version__)
import statsmodels; print("Statsmodels", statsmodels.__version__)
-->

Is there anyway in an auto_arima model to get the list of parameters. (For example p number of AR parameters, Q number of MA parameters,...)

items.title: Best Model Question
items.body:
Hi,

Because I have interest in doing Time Series analysis I started looking into your project :)

There are some cool features implemented so far!

What I want to ask is the following:

I looked into the results.summary() of my best model obtained with pmdarima.auto_arima() and I noticed that p-value(s) that reflects the residuals values used in results.plot_diagnostics() may not be good. Only one of them (Prob(Q) or Prob(JB)) have some time value greater than 0.05. Far as I know, and read about, both must be greater than 0.05 in order to have a best model. The residuals must be uncorrelated and normally distributed. I'm not sure if the minimum AIC is enough, we must have also resiudals in the previous mentioned condition, if they are not in this condition the model must be reworked. I assume that in this condition the looping through the possible models should go on. Is this judgement correct?

I also take a look in the obtained model (in results) and there is something like this "scoring='mse'". It means that the pmdarima.auto_arima() algorithm is splitting also the provided data and make an in-side prediction test? If is so can you tell me the proportion of the used data in this test?

I used this tool to find the best SARIMA model for some monthly time series. I used the following lines:

```python
# I split my data in 0.8 for training and 0.2 for testing
kpss_diffs = ndiffs(train, alpha=0.05, test='kpss', max_d=12)
adf_diffs = ndiffs(train, alpha=0.05, test='adf', max_d=12)
d = max(adf_diffs, kpss_diffs)

D = nsdiffs(train, m=12, max_D=12, test='ocsb')

results = pm.auto_arima(
    train, # data
    # Non-Seasonal Parameters
    d=d, # non-seasonal difference order
    start_p=0, max_p=12,
    start_q=0, max_q=12,
    # Seasonal Parameters
    seasonal=True,
    m=12, # the seasonal period (12 months) = the number of periods in each season
    D=D, # seasonal difference order
    start_P=0, max_P=12,
    start_Q=0, max_Q=12,
    information_criterion='aic', # used to select the best model
    stepwise=True, # apply inteligent order search
    suppress_warnings=True, # disable general warnings                      
    error_action="ignore" # disable ModelFitWarning(s)
)
results.summary()
```

Best regards,
George C.

items.title: [MAINT] Migrate versioning to tags only
items.body:
The explicit versioning is a bit of a pain to manage and can fail people's PRs if we aren't on our game. We should switch over to managing the version with a tag.

Rather than set the version explicitly:

```python
__version__ = '1.4.0'
```

We'll do something like:

```python
from pathlib import Path

try:
    version_path = Path(__file__).parent / "VERSION"
    version = version_path.read_text().strip()
except FileNotFoundError:
    version = "0.0.0"
```

Where the `VERSION` file is created by a Make target `make version` only in the presence of tags in CI jobs. That means local or dev versions will all be `0.0.0`.

Things that will need to change:

* [ ] Documentation for dev versions will need to read "dev" as the version rather than 0.0.0, since that would appear clunky and confusing to users
* [ ] `deploy-doc` stage will need to be updated
* [ ] `make` target for Circle (and MacOS jobs?)
* [ ] Windows needs a different approach, since it won't have cmake installed

Anything I'm missing?

items.title: [DOC] Misleading doc in SlidingWindowForecastCV

labels.name: good first issue
labels.description: A good opportunity for first-time contributors.

items.body:
As mentioned in the comment section of #201, there is a misleading statement in the [`SlidingWindowForecastCV`](https://github.com/tgsmith61591/pmdarima/blob/master/pmdarima/model_selection/_split.py#L200):

```
    step : int, optional (default=1)
        The size of step taken to increase the training sample size when not
        performing using a window.
```

This is an artifact of when both CV strategies were lumped into the same class. This should read:

```
    step : int, optional (default=1)
        The size of step taken between training folds.
```

Good issue for anyone looking to get involved.

items.title: tsCV support
items.body:
can you please supply a port of `tsCV`?
It's a very simple function, and for me it's the only reliable way of evaluating my out-of-sample model performance. I don't know if it belongs in `pmdarima` or in `statsmodels`, but it's definitely *not* the sklearn `TimeSeriesSplit`, `tsCV` is much better. 

Here's what I sketched for my internal needs, I'm pretty sure you have a more complete version you use for your own testing and evaluations:

```
def tsCV(y, model, h=1, step=1, window=None, xreg=None):
    n = len(y)
    if xreg:
        assert (len(xreg) == n)
    if not window:
        indx = range(1, n, step)
        e = np.zeros([(n - 1) // step, h])
    else:
        indx = range(window, n, step)
        e = np.zeros([(n - window) // step, h])
    start_params = None
    for out_i, i in enumerate(indx):
        start = 0 if not window else i - window
        assert i >= 0
        y_subset = y[start: i]

        if xreg:
            xreg_subset = xreg[start: i]
        else:
            xreg_subset = None
        if start_params:
            model.fit(y_subset, exogenous=xreg_subset, arima__start_params=start_params)
        else:
            model.fit(y_subset, exogenous=xreg_subset)
        preds = model.predict(n_periods=h)
        e[out_i, :] = y[i:i + h] - preds

    return e
```

items.title: Python 3.8 Support
items.body: [Python 3.8 was released on 2019-10-14.](https://docs.python.org/3/whatsnew/3.8.html) It appears to be fully backwards compatible, we just need to pre-build wheels for it. Currently, some of our dependencies do not support 3.8, so we will have to wait for them, but this issue is to track any conversation around 3.8 support

items.title: automatic InvBoxCox for predictions
items.body:
not entirely sure this is possible with your pipeline approach...

R's `forecast.arima` has a `lambda` parameter which calls an internal `Transformer` when it's not NONE. This enables it to automatically `InvBoxCox` the  predictions and the confidence intervals, which is very useful to users. (can't think of why would I want the transformed results, the original scale is the intuitive scale...)

NOTE that the metrics (log-likelihood, aic, bic...) are reported in the transformed scale, so this part is ok.

items.title: number of residuals from auto_arima is different from what I get from R
items.body:
I am comparing results of auto ARIMA with R (forecast package) and Python (pmdarima package). One of the issues I am getting is the length of the residuals in R and Python are different when d is not zero. For example, in the code shown below, in R, the length of the residuals is the same as the time series data but in python it is the length of the time series data minus d. Further, I also see significant changes in the order I get from R vs Python. What are the causes of the differences?
**R**
```library(forecast)
set.seed(250)
ts1 = arima.sim(list(order = c(1,1,0), ar = 0.7), n = 200)
set.seed(270)
ts2 = arima.sim(list(order = c(1,2,0), ar = 0.7), n = 200)
my_fit1 <- auto.arima(ts1, stepwise = FALSE)
resid1 = as.numeric(residuals(my_fit1))
my_fit2 <- auto.arima(ts2, stepwise = FALSE)
resid2 = as.numeric(residuals(my_fit2))
#to use with Python
 ts1 = data.frame(ts1 = ts1)
 write.csv(ts1, 'ts1.csv', row.names = F)
 ts2 = data.frame(ts2 = ts2)
 write.csv(ts2, 'ts2.csv', row.names = F)
```


**Python**
```import pandas as pd
from pmdarima.arima import auto_arima
ts1 = pd.read_csv('ts1.csv')
ts2 = pd.read_csv('ts2.csv')
my_fit1 = auto_arima(y = ts1.ts1, 
                  start_p=1, 
                  start_q=1,
                  max_p=3, 
                  max_q=3,
                  seasonal=False,
                  d = None,  
                  error_action='ignore',  
                  suppress_warnings=True, 
                  stepwise=False)

 my_fit2 = auto_arima(y = ts2.ts2, 
                  start_p=1, 
                  start_q=1,
                  max_p=3, 
                  max_q=3,
                  seasonal=False,
                  d = None,  
                  error_action='ignore',  
                  suppress_warnings=True, 
                  stepwise=False)```

I get this annoying bug when trying to fit my data with my generated Arima:

I am not entirely sure what it means, but upon googling i found this:
`The problem is that you need more observations to estimate the model.` from here:
https://github.com/statsmodels/statsmodels/issues/4465#issuecomment-380459136

The person also mentions that for a specific model atleast X observations are needed. Couldn't this relation be raised as an exception from your module? items.title: Difference between R and Python implementation of auto.arima
items.body:
**Question**
In the documentation, there is written:

> `pmdarima` is designed to behave as similarly to R’s well-known `auto.arima` as possible

Could someone answer the question, what are the differences?

1. I tried to run simple `ARIMA` (order is not important at the moment) on my dataset (1000 data points). Something like that:

```python
import pmdarima as pm
arima = pm.ARIMA(order=(0,1,1))
arima_fit = arima.fit(ts_data)
```
And it's pretty fast.

2. When I use the same dataset and use `auto_arima` function (like `pm.auto_arima(ts_data)`), it's taking a bit more time (measured with `timeit`):

> 1.07 s ± 53.1 ms per loop (mean ± std. dev. of 7 runs, 1 loop each)

R implementation of `auto.arima` is roughly 10 times faster. What's the reason? Is there a way how to improve that?

3. When I take the same dataset and use R and Python implementations of auto ARIMA I get (depends on data) different results. The default parameters seem to be the same. What's the reason for that? 

**Versions**
Windows-10-10.0.17134-SP0
Python 3.6.8 |Anaconda, Inc.| (default, Feb 21 2019, 18:30:04) [MSC v.1916 64 bit (AMD64)]
pmdarima 1.2.1
NumPy 1.16.4
SciPy 1.2.1
Scikit-Learn 0.20.2
Statsmodels 0.9.0

items.body:

But after that, when I want to import **auto_arima**:
```from pyramid.arima import auto_arima```

items.title: CI/CD failing due to version upgrades
items.body:
Our CI/CD seems to be failing. This issue is primarily to track conversation around that. Here are my observations around that. I also have a [branch open for it.](https://github.com/tgsmith61591/pmdarima/tree/fix-ci-cd)

- [X] `pytest` >= 5.0 now requires `str(error.value)` instead of `str(error)` to inspect error messages 
- [ ] Newest `statsmodel` may have broken some of our tests? I am looking at [this test](https://github.com/tgsmith61591/pmdarima/blob/fix-ci-cd/pmdarima/arima/tests/test_arima.py#L707-L719), with [this output](https://dev.azure.com/tgsmith61591gh/pmdarima/_build/results?buildId=154&view=logs&jobId=b1153b9e-c3f0-5b89-ade2-5e81f2ff323e&taskId=edb4f60d-432d-5ecb-d94c-0add79e727e3&lineStart=56&lineEnd=70&colStart=5&colEnd=1). One thing to note is that there is a comment that says `# todo: can we do something more informative in case the error is not on the pmdarima side?`. Could this have been solved? We _are_ getting a `UserWarning` emitted, but not its subclass of `ModelFitWarning`
- [ ] All of our plotting tests seem to have broken.
- [ ] [`scikit-learn` not on Conda?](https://travis-ci.org/tgsmith61591/pmdarima/jobs/553838732#L1979-L1981)

Let me know if I missed anything

items.title: RFC: Move away from gitflow
items.body:
### Description

 We currently use the [gitflow](https://nvie.com/posts/a-successful-git-branching-model/) branching model, and some of our CI/CD practices and assumptions rely heavily on it. However, there are some drawbacks:

* Harder for new contributors to get the flow (pardon the pun) of our merging practices
* Lower visibility from issue-watchers into the resolution, as fixes never make it into master until a release happens

And more pros to moving off of it, IMO:

* Increased perception that we're responding to issues in a timely manner
* Easier for new contributors to submit PRs to the `master` branch than having to correct the PR every time
* In situations where pypi releases are broken (like due to the statsmodels/scipy bug when scipy upgraded to 1.13 and statsmodels was still behind), it's easier to instruct users to build from source on master than from some obscure `develop` branch
* Less likely to get merge conflicts in PRs because forks are probably not going to be based on the most bleeding edge branch

### Proposal

Prior to 1.3.0 I think we should move away from gitflow merging practices. Here are the changes required

* PRs will merge straight into `master`
* Releases will still be triggered by tagging
* We'll no longer manually version the package; we'll allow git tags to manage the versioning, and development versions will use a dummy version
* Bleeding edge (`develop`) documentation will now be published on `master` rather than `develop`
* Release documentation will now be published on releases rather than `master`
* Contributions instructions will have to change
* (`anything else?...`)

#### Thoughts please?

items.title: pmdarima imports from `sklearn.externals`, which raises a warning
items.body:
`sklearn.externals.six` and `sklearn.externals.joblib` have been deprecated in the latest version of `sklearn`. Unfortunately, various code in pmdarima imports directly from these deprecated packages. Thus, when I run:

```python
from pmdarima.arima import auto_arima
```

I get a bunch of garbage warnings printed to my stdout:

```
/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/sklearn/externals/six.py:31: DeprecationWarning: The module is deprecated in version 0.21 and will be removed in version 0.23 since we've dropped support for Python 2.7. Please rely on the official version of six (https://pypi.org/project/six/).
  "(https://pypi.org/project/six/).", DeprecationWarning)
/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/sklearn/externals/joblib/__init__.py:15: DeprecationWarning: sklearn.externals.joblib is deprecated in 0.21 and will be removed in 0.23. Please import this functionality directly from joblib, which can be installed with: pip install joblib. If this warning is raised when loading pickled models, you may need to re-serialize those models with scikit-learn 0.21+.
  warnings.warn(msg, category=DeprecationWarning)
```

Like the warnings say, it would be better if pmdarima depended upon the actual `six` and `joblib` packages, instead of the ones currently (but not for much longer) bundled with `sklearn`.
